#Text=Aragon
#Text=Aragon ( Spanish and Aragonese : Aragón , Catalan : Aragó ) is a region in the north of Spain .

#Text=Despite seeing limited tourist traffic compared to other regions , it holds a wealth of unique sights , with villages and towns rich in architectural history picturesquely extending on the hillsides and in the valleys in the midst of the barren , mountainous countryside
#Text=Cities
#Text=Zaragoza , capital of Aragon , also known as Saragossa in English
#Text=Barbastro
#Text=Calatayud
#Text=Huesca
#Text=Jaca
#Text=Monegros
#Text=Teruel , capital of the namesake province , with a wealth of picturesque architectural heritage
#Text=Toria
#Text=Towns and villages
#Text=Ainsa
#Text=Albarracín , town in Teruel province , noted for its pink-hued sandstone buildings
#Text=Alquezar
#Text=Campo
#Text=Canfranc
#Text=Graus
#Text=Murillo de Gallego
#Text=Villanueva de Sigena
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=( Huesca ) . is the third highest mountain in the Pyrenees .
#Text=( Zaragoza )
#Text=Understand

#Text=Aragon is the heart of what was in the Middle Ages the Crown of Aragon , which also included regions like Valencia , Murcia , Catalonia , the Balearic Islands , Venice , the South of Italy , Sicily and some Greek colonies .
#Text=In the 15th its King Ferdinand married Isabel of Castile and formed the Kingdom of Spain .
#Text=Although it used to have its own language , Aragonese , and laws , over the centuries most of them were lost and it became more like Castile .
#Text=Nowadays , Aragon , despite its large size , has a population of only 1 million , making it largely uninhabited , with the capital , Zaragoza , holding over half the population .
#Text=Nature
#Text=Some interesting plants even for a non-biologist are :
#Text=Blackberry : can be found on the slopes of Guara and Pireneus mountains .
#Text=Acorn : There are two types of non-oak acorn , at least one of them grows on bushes rather than on trees .
#Text=Talk
#Text=Spanish is spoken in Aragon by the whole population .
#Text=Aragonese ( Aragonese or Castilian : aragonés , also known as fabla ) , is spoken in the north , but is not recognized as an official language .
#Text=This language is similar to Catalan and Castilian with some Basque and Occitan influences .
#Text=Catalan is also spoken in the East of the region ( Catalan : Franja de Ponent , literally
#Text=West Strip , being West of Catalunya ) , though it has no official status .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Aragon is connected to France by roads and tunnels ( Somport ) but not by train .
#Text=It has no coast , so it 's not accessible by boat .
#Text=There is an airport in Zaragoza ( ZAZ ) , served by low-fare carriers offering flights to secondary airports in some European countries , as well as domestic flights .

#Text=As the Madrid-Barcelona high-speed railway line runs through Aragon , you can also use the airports in Madrid – Barajas Airport ( MAD ) and Barcelona ( BCN ) , which offer many more international and intercontinental connections .
#Text=By car
#Text=Roads are really good in the region and its towns .
#Text=Even if you go canyoning or other active sports , typically you do n't need a 4x4 , as you always leave car on a parking near starting point of activities .
#Text=By bike
#Text=Cycling is very popular sports in the region , and the roads are really good .
#Text=See
#Text=Isabena valley , a beautiful but very desolate valley in the alta ribagorza
#Text=Mudéjar Architecture of Aragon — ten UNESCO World Heritage List ed buildings around the region
#Text=Monte Perdido/Mont Perdu — located at the border to France , it 's the third tallest mountain in the Pyrenees and inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List
#Text=Do
#Text=Rock climbing : Los Mallos for serious climbers .
#Text=Hydrospeed : Ideal time is April-May , as it requires much water in the rivers .
#Text=Whitewater rafting : Multiple operators and a kayaking school can be found in the town of Campo ; some rafting can be found in Murillo de Gallego .
#Text=Aguas Blancas .
#Text=Hiking : routes can be find in Senderos turisticos de Aragon .
#Text=Also , you might want to follow the guides of Sobrarbe geopark , where you can find a lot of hinkings trails .
#Text=You can download a gpx file with 351 tracks here , and you can find the individual files here .

#Text=Canyoning : According to outdoor activities operators , Aragon canyons are the best in Europe ( most long and intensive ) and third in the world -- and there are up to 150 canyons available in the region .
#Text=In summer , about 16 canyons are in active use .
#Text=May is ideal time for experienced canyoners : almost every canyon have just enough water , and water is warm enough .
#Text=June-July and September is good for well-fit canyoners .
#Text=August is a peak season for non-experienced canyoners looking for fun with minimal effort .
#Text=Canyons are both in Sierra de Guara and Pireneus .
#Text=In the whole region , there 's no places for horizontal abseiling ( like moving over a rope above a river from one side of canyon to another ) .
#Text=Most canyons were originally discovered and gone through in 1970s .
#Text=Alquezar is the main starting point for canyons in Aragon .
#Text=Equipment to bring for commercial canyoning specific for this region : shoes for slippery stones .
#Text=Canyons

#Text=Aigueta de Barbaruens : Features : About 15 jumps up to 10m ( several of them in quite unexpected locations ) ; 2 to 4 abseils ( two of them are better as high jumps ) ; several slides , including 5m-long and a twisting one ( hands-up only ) .

#Text=T-shirt is recommended on your way from parking to the canyon : windy even in August ; no direct sunlight ; bush is not always easy to go through . 70 % of canyoning time is spent without direct sunlight .
#Text=Serious level difference between entry and exit .
#Text=In late August , very clean water well under 10°C .
#Text=Alcanadre
#Text=Balces
#Text=Basender
#Text=Cabrito
#Text=Chimiachas
#Text=Formiga : Typical durations : 3 hours in canyon ; 45min walk to entry to canyon from nearest parking ; 20min to walk from exit from canyon to parking .

#Text=Features : several jumps ( up to 7m ) ; about 5 slides ( one face-down ; another with 2-3m high jump ) ; two jump-unders ; two abseils ( one dry at the entry , and one near waterfall with slippery vertical rock ) .
#Text=Small section of via ferrata preceding the entry .
#Text=In late August , very clean 14°C water .
#Text=No T-shirt is necessary .
#Text=Fornocal : exit is 2nd closest to Alquezar
#Text=Monzon
#Text=Pionera
#Text=Portiacha
#Text=Río Vero : exit is closest to Alquezar
